prelude.value: It’s officially summer and you’re looking for your next read. But you don’t want to read what everyone else is reading. No, you want something more obscure. You’ll take the books that no one is reading. Better yet, how about the books no one has touched in years?

We (programmatically) sifted through over 100 million checkout records from the Seattle Public Library to find books that haven’t been checked out in over a decade*. Sounds like they’re just your speed.

minimapHed: There are 000 books in this stack
sidebarHed: Use the filters below to find books you may like

sortButtons.description: Least to most number of Goodreads ratings.

conclusion.value: Libraries are treasure troves of stories and resources that are both widely used and collecting dust. Just by showing up, getting a library card, and checking out books (or movies, or TV shows, or internet hotspots), you are supporting your local library.

If you still haven’t found your perfect summer read here, you may want to check out the more “mainstream” reading suggestions from Mental Floss, The Boston Globe, Elle, The Washington Post, NPR, The New York Times, and GoodReads. Or head to your local library and ask for suggestions. Happy reading!

method.value: All books discussed in this article are fiction books that have appeared in the Seattle Public Library’s physical book inventory for the entire span of time between September 2017 and May 2019 (the earliest and latest dates available for these data), but have not been checked out any time between September 2005 and May 2019. We excluded any books that were published after 2005.

There is a chance that although all the books we analyzed were published prior to 2005, the library may not have had them in inventory during the entire time period between 2005 and the writing of this article. So, at a minimum, the books have been in the inventory for 1.5 years (and have gone unchecked out at that entire time), but it’s more likely that these older books weren’t checked out in nearly 14 years (or longer since our checkout data only goes back to 2005).

Both checkout and inventory data are publicly available thanks to the Seattle Public Library. You can view our processed data and the R scripts used to process the data here. All rating data available comes from GoodReads.

Many thanks to David Christensen from the SPL who answered a ton of our more detailed data quandaries and thanks to Isabel Carter and Swati Murugappan for help with manual data collection of book details.
Be advised that reading a book from this list will guarantee that you are more interesting at your next adult party where everyone else is just talking about the last podcast they listened to.
